hero.label: Competition Format
hero.heading: FORMAT & RULES
hero.description: Everything you need to know about how Battle Royale works—from team composition to score normalization.

cashPrizes.title: Cash Prizes
cashPrizes.description: $25K per event. $100K total in Year 1. 1st: $15K. 2nd: $7.5K. 3rd: $2.5K. Teams 4th–8th get merch prizes.

mixedTeams.title: Mixed Teams
mixedTeams.description: 64 team spots per event. Minimum 3 gymnasts, no max. Teams can be all women, all men, or any mix.

invitational.title: Invitational
invitational.description: Open to all gymnasts 16+ who can perform FIG-level routines. No federation restrictions or qualification requirements.

fourEvents.title: 4 Events Per Year
fourEvents.description: Year 1 runs Nov 2026 – Jun 2027. Each event is one day: qualification, semi-final, and final.

eliminationFormat.title: Elimination Format
eliminationFormat.description: 64 teams qualify, 12 advance to semi-finals, 4 make the finals. Progressively fewer routines with higher stakes.

figJudging.title: FIG Judging
figJudging.description: Same routines. Same judging criteria. Same FIG rules. Just normalized scores for fair cross-apparatus comparison.

teamComposition.heading: TEAM COMPOSITION & ELIGIBILITY
teamComposition.subheading: Who can compete and how teams are formed.

ageRequirements.title: AGE REQUIREMENTS
ageRequirements.description: Athletes must be at least 16 years old on the day of the event. There is no upper age limit.

skillLevel.title: SKILL LEVEL
skillLevel.description: Athletes should be capable of performing FIG Senior-level routines. This typically means competitive Level 10, Elite, or NCAA-level gymnasts for WAG, and Level 10 or Elite for MAG.
skillLevel.routineNote: A FIG routine consists of 6-8 elements from the FIG Code of Points.

teamComposition.title: TEAM COMPOSITION
items: Teams can be all women, all men, or any mix
Gymnasts from different clubs can form teams together—no club or federation restrictions
Each gymnast may only compete on one team per event

nationalTeamLimit.title: NATIONAL TEAM LIMIT
nationalTeamLimit.description: To prevent "super teams" in the early seasons, each team may only include one current national team member. This ensures competitive balance and gives all teams a fair chance.

apparelRequirements.title: APPAREL REQUIREMENTS
apparelRequirements.description: No singlet requirement. Teams must have 2 main team colors and wear matching, non-baggy attire. Express your team's identity however you want—this is about entertainment and team spirit.

apparatus.heading: APPARATUS
apparatus.description: The events that make up Battle Royale competition.
apparatus.mixedTeams: Mixed teams can use any combination of these 8 apparatus.

whyNoPommel.title: WHY NO POMMEL HORSE OR PARALLEL BARS?
whyNoPommel.description: We've streamlined the men's apparatus to 4 events to match women's gymnastics. Pommel Horse was removed because it's often the trickiest event for gymnasts and prone to falls. Parallel Bars was removed because routines take the longest—and we're focused on an action-packed spectator experience.
whyNoPommel.kept: We kept Still Rings (iconic strength event), High Bar (spectacular releases and dismounts), plus Vault and Floor (shared with women's).

scoreNormalization.heading: SCORE NORMALIZATION
scoreNormalization.description: The breakthrough that makes Battle Royale possible.

problem.title: THE PROBLEM
problem.description: In traditional FIG gymnastics, different apparatus have different maximum scores based on the difficulty of skills available. A 15.5 on vault means something different than a 15.5 on beam. This makes it impossible to:
items: Compare WAG (women's) and MAG (men's) scores directly
Create mixed-gender teams that compete fairly
Help casual viewers understand who's winning

solution.title: THE SOLUTION
solution.description: Score Normalization: We take the standard FIG score and scale it based on the highest possible start value for that apparatus. The result is a final score out of 10.
solution.example: This means a 9.2 on beam can be directly compared to a 9.2 on high bar. Spectators instantly understand the quality of each routine. Mixed WAG/MAG teams become possible and fair.

whatStaysSame.title: WHAT STAYS THE SAME
items: Athletes perform their existing FIG routines—no changes required
Judges use standard FIG Code of Points
Difficulty (D) scores and Execution (E) scores work the same way
Deductions for falls, errors, and execution remain unchanged

judging.heading: JUDGING & SCORING
judging.description: How routines are evaluated and scores are calculated.

structure.title: JUDGING STRUCTURE
structure.description: In the qualification round, we use two panels per event, with each panel consisting of one judge who evaluates both Difficulty and Execution for maximum speed.
structure.system: The system works like this: One gymnast competes, and the moment they finish, the first panel starts judging them. While the first panel is judging, the next gymnast competes while the second panel judges them. When they finish, the panels swap. This means there's always someone competing at all times—we must respect strict time restraints.
structure.judges: We only select the best of the best judges: those who are fast, accurate, and unbiased. This streamlined approach ensures constant action while maintaining the highest judging standards.

codeOfPoints.title: CODE OF POINTS
codeOfPoints.description: Judges use the FIG Code of Points (current cycle). Judges use the same deductions, difficulty values, and execution standards they're already trained on.
codeOfPoints.normalization: Score normalization doesn't affect judging at all. Judges judge routines normally using FIG standards. The normalization calculation happens after scores are submitted—it's a mathematical transformation applied to make scores comparable across apparatus.

scoreSubmission.title: SCORE SUBMISSION
scoreSubmission.description: Judges submit scores using the Judges Companion app, a helper app built into Gym Art Meets. This is our in-house application designed for maximum speed and super easy use.
scoreSubmission.process: You simply input an FIG score, and the score normalization happens automatically in the background. On the scoreboard, spectators see the normalized score out of 10—all done seamlessly without changing your judging process.

qualification.title: QUALIFICATION
items: Four qualification rounds, each lasting 80 minutes
All scores count towards team total

semiFinals.title: SEMI-FINALS
items: 120-second time limit per routine (no extra time for falls)

finals.title: FINALS
items: 4 teams gather in the center of the arena
One athlete competes at a time, rotating between teams

appointmentScheduling.title: APPOINTMENT-BASED SCHEDULING
appointmentScheduling.description: Unlike traditional competitions where teams rotate through apparatus together, Battle Royale uses appointment-based scheduling.
appointmentScheduling.example: Each athlete receives a specific time for their routine. For example: "Athlete A - Uneven Bars at 9:05 AM, Athlete B - Vault at 9:10 AM." Multiple athletes can compete simultaneously on different apparatus.
appointmentScheduling.benefit: This creates a more dynamic, action-packed viewing experience with constant activity across the competition floor. Detailed schedules are released close to each event.

timeLimits.title: TIME LIMITS & FALLS
timeLimits.semiFinalsFinals: Semi-Finals & Finals: There's a 120-second hard limit per routine with no extensions.
timeLimits.falls: Falls are deducted per standard FIG rules. Skills performed after the time limit don't count.

tieBreaking.title: TIE-BREAKING RULES
tieBreaking.description: We follow FIG regulations for breaking ties:

deathMatch.title: DEATH MATCH
deathMatch.description: If it's still a true tie, we go to a death match: both teams send up one athlete (or two) to perform routines. The sum of those routines determines the final winner.

registration.heading: REGISTRATION & LOGISTICS
registration.description: Everything you need to know about registering and attending events.

pricing.title: REGISTRATION PRICING
pricing.note: Early bird discounts and dynamic pricing may apply based on demand.

timeline.title: REGISTRATION TIMELINE
timeline.description: Registration opens 4 months before each event:

process.title: REGISTRATION PROCESS
process.description: Register your team through the Gym Art Meets platform when registration opens. You'll need:
items: Payment via credit card or bank transfer

warmUps.title: WARM-UPS
warmUps.description: Teams will have scheduled warm-up times before their competition rounds. Detailed warm-up schedules will be provided closer to each event. The single-day format means efficient warm-up rotations.

venueLocations.title: VENUE LOCATIONS
venueLocations.description: All Season 1 events are in Ontario and Quebec, Canada.
venueLocations.note: Specific venues will be announced as they're confirmed. We're targeting venues with good spectator capacity and professional gymnastics equipment.

cancellationPolicy.title: CANCELLATION POLICY
cancellationPolicy.description: In the unlikely event of cancellation, full refunds will be provided for registration and ticket purchases. We have backup venue plans and flexible scheduling (unlike federation events locked to specific dates).

prizes.heading: PRIZE BREAKDOWN
prizes.merchandise: Teams finishing 4th–8th receive exclusive Battle Royale merchandise.
prizes.goal: Our goal: scale to $250K per competition
